guide.name: Semantic Weaver Sync Guide
guide.description: Instructions for AI agents to convert documents into Semantic Weaver's Context Markup Language (CML), Context Markup Language for Documentation (CMLD), and Markdown-LD formats for RDF integration in Obsidian, addressing ambiguity in text and ontologies (e.g., language or regional differences).

formats.name: CML/CMLD
formats.description: Context Markup Language (CML) and Context Markup Language for Documentation (CMLD) for annotating Markdown notes with RDF metadata, designed to resolve ambiguities in unstructured text or linked-data ontologies. See https://mediaprophet.github.io/init-draft-standards-wip/cml/ and https://mediaprophet.github.io/init-draft-standards-wip/CMLD/.

cml.description: Used for general RDF annotations without @doc prefix, including contextual disambiguation (e.g., clarifying 'Washington' as a state or person).
rules: Subject is enclosed in square brackets, e.g., [Washington].
Predicates and values are separated by a colon (:).
Multiple predicate-value pairs are separated by semicolons (;).
Objects can be URIs (in square brackets) or literals (in quotes for strings).
Use namespace prefixes from ontology, e.g., ex: for http://example.org/.
Use ex:refersTo for contextual disambiguation, e.g., [Washington]{ex:refersTo=ex:State_Washington}.

cmld.description: Used for document metadata with @doc prefix, supporting contextual metadata.
rules: Start with @doc followed by subject in square brackets.
Follows same predicate-value pair rules as CML.
Typically used for document-level metadata like category, author, created.

conversion.input: Any document with identifiable entities and relationships, potentially ambiguous (e.g., 'Washington' as a state or person).

output.markdown: Insert CML or CMLD annotations at the top or bottom of the Markdown file.

example.input: This is a note about a project meeting held on July 15, 2025, with John as the author, discussing Washington.

steps: Identify key entities (e.g., documents, people, locations) and their relationships.
Detect potential ambiguities (e.g., 'Washington' as state, person, or city) and resolve using context (e.g., document content, regional references).
Map entities to ontology terms (e.g., doc:Document, ex:Person) from semantic-weaver/ontology.ttl or semantic-weaver/ontology/*.md.
Generate CML for relationships and disambiguation (e.g., [Washington] ex:refersTo: [ex:State_Washington]).
Generate CMLD for document metadata (e.g., @doc [Note] category: "Documentation").
Append annotations to the Markdown file.

formats.name: Markdown-LD
formats.description: Markdown-LD syntax for defining RDF ontologies in semantic-weaver/ontology/*.md files, based on schema.org and RDFa.

syntax.description: Uses inline attributes in square brackets with typeof and property annotations, and footnote-style namespace declarations.
rules: Define namespaces at the top with [prefix]: URI (e.g., [schema]: http://schema.org).
Entities are enclosed in square brackets, e.g., [Person].
Attributes are specified in curly braces, e.g., {typeof=rdfs:Class}.
Multiple properties are space-separated, e.g., {typeof=rdfs:Property rdfs:label="Name"}.
Use schema.org, rdfs, or owl vocabularies for types and properties.
Save files in semantic-weaver/ontology/ with .md extension.

conversion.input: Ontology definitions in plain text, Turtle, or other RDF formats.

output.markdown: Markdown file with Markdown-LD syntax, saved in semantic-weaver/ontology/.

steps: Identify classes, properties, and relationships in the input ontology.
Map to schema.org, rdfs, or owl vocabularies (refer to semantic-weaver/ontology.ttl).
Define namespaces at the top of the Markdown file (e.g., [schema]: http://schema.org).
Convert properties to [Property]{typeof=rdfs:Property schema:domainIncludes=[Class]; schema:rangeIncludes=[Type]; rdfs:label="Label"}.
Save as a .md file in semantic-weaver/ontology/, e.g., my-ontology.md.
